experiments.hypothesis: Extreme funding rates (±0.010%) predict poor trade outcomes due to overcrowded positioning
experiments.methodology: Permutation test (10k) + walk-forward consistency (5 folds) + economic significance + mandatory/weighted criteria
experiments.failure_reason: Filter removes more winning trades (41) than losing trades (27), resulting in net negative R impact (-128.5R). Statistical significance is misleading - PF improved because removing ANY trade with below-average R/R will mechanically improve PF. This is survivorship bias, not predictive power.
experiments.key_learning: PF improvement alone is insufficient validation. Must verify filter has selective power (removes more losers than winners) AND improves net R. Statistical tests can pass while economic impact is negative.
experiments.notes: Permutation p=0.0111 PASSED, WF 4/5 folds PASSED, but Economic test FAILED. Filter lacks predictive power - randomly removing trades would produce similar PF improvement. Proceed with BASE system (no funding filter) for paper trading.
experiments.next_action: Paper trade BASE system (no funding filter). Add inverse hypothesis to Priority 2 backlog: test if extreme funding IMPROVES outcomes (momentum/trend confirmation).
experiments.inverse_hypothesis: Extreme funding rates may indicate strong momentum that HELPS trend-following QML patterns rather than hurting them. Worth testing positive funding → LONG only, negative funding → SHORT only.

research_backlog.hypothesis: Extreme funding rates indicate momentum that helps QML trend-following (inverse of original hypothesis)
research_backlog.rationale: Original filter removed more winners than losers, suggesting extreme funding may actually help rather than hurt
